childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1997-2009

You were born the year Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel and a sheep named Dolly proved cloning wasn't just science fiction. Hong Kong went back to China. Tony Blair became Prime Minister. The first Harry Potter book quietly appeared on shelves, which would come to define your entire generation's reading habits and personality categorization system.

Your childhood was the last gasp of the pre-smartphone world. You probably had a VHS collection before your family upgraded to DVDs. You watched Nickelodeon and Cartoon Network on a boxy television with a remote that never had working batteries. If your parents needed to reach you, they called the house and left a message on the answering machine.

You were four when 9/11 happened. Too young to understand, old enough to sense that something fundamental had shifted. The adults around you were scared in ways they tried to hide. Security became a constant presence—at airports, at schools, in the background of everything. You've never known a world without the War on Terror.

You were six when the Iraq War started. Seven when Facebook launched (though you wouldn't use it for years). Eight when YouTube went live and Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans. Ten when the iPhone dropped and changed everything. Eleven when the 2008 financial crisis wiped out your parents' savings and made adults suddenly very worried about money.

Your childhood saw technology transform from novelty to necessity. You probably got your first phone—a flip phone, maybe a Razr—around middle school. Your first smartphone came in high school. You're not quite a digital native, but you're close enough that the distinction barely matters.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen Z

You're Gen Z, born between 1997 and 2012. Pew Research drew the line at 1997 because that was before most people had access to the internet, before Google existed, before the world went fully digital. You're the oldest members of your generation—the ones who remember life before smartphones, even if barely.

Your generation is roughly 68 million people in the US, making you a massive demographic force. You're more diverse than any previous generation. You're the first generation for whom same-sex marriage has always been legal (at least from your teenage years onward). You don't remember a world where the president wasn't Black, then immediately followed by the most chaotic administration in modern history.

The defining experience for Gen Z is constant connectivity and constant crisis. You grew up with smartphones, social media, and the perpetual awareness that the world is on fire—sometimes literally. Climate anxiety is your generation's baseline emotional state. School shootings are something you've practiced surviving since elementary school.

You've been called pragmatic, anxious, entrepreneurial, and depressed—sometimes all in the same article. You don't remember economic stability, so you don't expect it. You don't remember a functional political system, so you've built your own communities online. You're less interested in reforming institutions and more interested in working around them entirely.

Your generation communicates in memes, builds identity through curated social feeds, and has a relationship with irony so deep that genuine emotion requires a disclaimer. You're simultaneously the most connected generation in history and the loneliest.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Titanic became the highest-grossing film of all time, the year teenage Leo DiCaprio made everyone lose their minds. Men in Black introduced Will Smith as the world's coolest alien fighter. Good Will Hunting gave us Matt Damon solving math problems on a chalkboard. The Full Monty proved British dudes could strip with dignity.

Musically, 1997 was Spice Girls world domination. 'Wannabe' and 'Spice Up Your Life' were inescapable. Elton John rewrote 'Candle in the Wind' for Diana's funeral, and it became the best-selling single of all time. Radiohead released OK Computer, which predicted the digital alienation you'd grow up experiencing.

TV in 1997 gave the world South Park, which would spend the next three decades offending everyone equally. Buffy the Vampire Slayer started. Ellen came out on her sitcom, which was revolutionary then and feels almost quaint now given how far LGBTQ+ representation has come.

Your childhood pop culture was dominated by Harry Potter (you grew up alongside the characters), SpongeBob SquarePants (which premiered when you were two), and whatever Disney Channel original movies were on that weekend. Your tween years belonged to Hannah Montana, High School Musical, and the Jonas Brothers. You probably had a strong opinion about whether you were Team Edward or Team Jacob.

Your teenage years saw the rise of YouTube stars, Vine comedians, and influencers who became famous for being famous. You watched pop culture fragment from monoculture into algorithm-driven niches. There's no shared cultural moment anymore—just whatever content your feed decided to show you.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Deep Blue beat Garry Kasparov at chess, the first time a computer defeated a human world champion at anything that mattered. It was a preview of the AI anxiety your generation would eventually inherit. Also in 1997: the domain google.com was registered. The company that would organize (and monetize) human knowledge was just getting started.

You were three when the Y2K panic happened. Too young to remember, but your parents probably worried the world would end because computers couldn't handle a date change. It didn't, but the anxiety about technology failing catastrophically never really went away.

You were seven when Facebook launched for college students. Ten when the iPhone arrived. Eleven when the App Store opened. By the time you were a teenager, smartphones weren't luxury items—they were how you communicated, socialized, and understood the world. You can't remember not having internet in your pocket.

Social media shaped your adolescence in ways previous generations can't fully grasp. You've been performing a version of yourself online since middle school. You've watched people get famous for 15-second videos. You've seen careers destroyed by screenshots. The concept of privacy is something older people explain to you like it's a foreign concept.

You're the first generation to grow up with algorithmic content curation. Your reality is shaped by what systems decide to show you. You're aware of this in ways that are both empowering and terrifying. You know the feed is manipulated, but you can't look away.

AI assistants have been part of your life since high school. Siri launched when you were fourteen. Alexa when you were eighteen. ChatGPT when you were twenty-five. The machines that seemed novel to your parents seem inevitable to you.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were four months old when Princess Diana died in that Paris tunnel. The global mourning was unprecedented—a billion people watched the funeral. You don't remember it, but it was the first media event of the 24-hour news cycle era, the template for collective grief in the internet age.

You were four during 9/11. Old enough to sense the fear, too young to process the politics. You grew up in the aftermath—the security theater, the wars, the surveillance state. Your entire conscious life has happened in a country at war somewhere.

You were six when the Iraq War started. Ten when an African American man was elected president. Eleven when the economy collapsed and your parents suddenly seemed very stressed about things you didn't understand. The 2008 financial crisis shaped your family's finances, your expectations about stability, and your skepticism about institutions.

You were fifteen when Sandy Hook happened. Twenty children your age, killed in their classroom. You'd already been doing lockdown drills for years. After Sandy Hook, they got more frequent, more realistic. Your generation practiced hiding from shooters the way previous generations practiced hiding from nuclear bombs.

You were eighteen when marriage equality became the law of the land. Nineteen when Donald Trump won the presidency. Twenty when the Parkland shooting sparked a youth movement for gun control. Twenty-two when COVID shut down the world. Twenty-three when an insurrection stormed the Capitol.

You've lived through more historical inflection points before age thirty than most generations experience in a lifetime. Climate disasters, political upheaval, economic crises, a global pandemic—these aren't news stories to you. They're the texture of your existence.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce around 2019-2020, which means COVID probably derailed whatever career trajectory you thought you had. Internships got cancelled. Entry-level jobs evaporated. Remote onboarding became normal, which meant learning office culture through a screen while trying to figure out if your camera angle made you look professional.

Your generation doesn't expect employer loyalty because you've never seen it. Your parents got laid off in 2008. You watched them scramble. The implicit promise of 'work hard and you'll be taken care of' was broken before you ever had a chance to believe it.

You're entrepreneurial by necessity. Side hustles aren't optional—they're how you survive. You sell things on Depop, drive for DoorDash, monetize TikTok, or freelance on Fiverr. The gig economy isn't a choice; it's the only economy available to you.

You negotiate differently than previous generations. You're comfortable talking about salary on social media. You share compensation data openly. The taboo about discussing money that your parents observed seems ridiculous to you—how else are you supposed to know if you're being underpaid?

Remote work is your default. You've never known a world where 'the office' was the only place work happened. You're skeptical of commutes, suspicious of mandatory in-person meetings, and completely unromantic about corporate culture. The ping pong table in the break room doesn't impress you. Fair wages and work-life balance do.

You're also entering a job market that's being transformed by AI in real-time. The skills you learned in college are already being automated. Adaptation isn't a nice-to-have—it's survival.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You've been dating-app-native since you started dating. Tinder launched when you were sixteen. Bumble when you were eighteen. By the time you were old enough to seriously date, swiping was the norm. You don't know what it's like to meet someone without already knowing their Instagram aesthetic.

Your generation invented the 'talking stage'—that liminal space between matching and officially dating that can last weeks or months. You're experts at maintaining ambiguity, partly because commitment feels risky, partly because you've seen too many relationships play out publicly online.

You communicate through layers of mediation. DMs, Stories, BeReals, Snaps. Each platform has different rules, different audiences, different versions of yourself. Managing these digital selves is exhausting, but you've been doing it so long you don't know how to stop.

You're having less sex than previous generations, which older people find confusing and younger researchers find concerning. The reasons are complicated: phones in bedrooms, dating app fatigue, economic stress, mental health struggles. Whatever the cause, physical intimacy is happening less often and later in life.

Friendships for your generation often exist primarily online. Your closest friends might live across the country. Group chats are where your real community happens. This felt isolating during COVID, when online was the only option, but it also meant you were more prepared for digital connection than any generation before you.

You've normalized discussing mental health, boundaries, and attachment styles in ways that would mystify your grandparents. Therapy-speak is your native language. Whether this makes relationships healthier or just more self-conscious is still being debated.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were eleven when the 2008 financial crisis happened. You watched your parents lose jobs, lose homes, lose the retirement savings they'd been counting on. You absorbed the lesson that economic security is an illusion, that stability can vanish overnight, that institutions promising safety are lying.

You entered adulthood during COVID, which was another economic implosion. Two massive financial crises before you turned twenty-five. Your financial worldview is less 'plan for the future' and more 'survive the present.'

Student debt defines your economic reality. The average graduate in your cohort owes around $30,000. The jobs available don't pay enough to service that debt and also pay rent. The math doesn't work, and you know it doesn't work, and nobody in charge seems to care.

Housing is a distant dream. You've watched prices climb while wages stayed flat. The down payment you'd need is more than you make in a year. Renting forever isn't a lifestyle choice—it's the only option available. You're not buying fewer houses because you're spending money on avocado toast. You're not buying houses because houses cost half a million dollars.

Your generation invests differently. You're into crypto, meme stocks, and fractional shares bought through apps. Traditional financial advice—'max out your 401(k), buy index funds, wait forty years'—assumes a stability you've never experienced. You're gambling because the house always wins anyway.

You're also more likely to spend on experiences rather than things. Concerts, travel, meals out. Not because you're irresponsible, but because owning things feels impossible and experiencing things feels achievable. If you can't have the house, at least you can have the memory.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's biggest weakness is the conflation of awareness with action. You know about every problem—climate change, inequality, systemic racism, mental health crises—but knowing about problems isn't the same as solving them. Sometimes the constant awareness creates paralysis. You're so overwhelmed by everything that needs fixing that you fix nothing.

You're so accustomed to performing authenticity online that you've lost track of what authenticity actually feels like. Every emotional moment is potentially content. Every opinion is potentially engagement. The line between genuine experience and shareable experience has blurred to the point of invisibility.

Your irony is a defense mechanism that sometimes prevents genuine connection. Everything is a joke, a reference, a meme. Earnestness feels cringe. But some things—love, grief, hope—don't survive being ironized. By refusing to be sincere, you rob yourself of experiences that require sincerity.

You've been told you're special your whole life, which creates both entitlement and crushing disappointment when the world fails to recognize your specialness. The gap between expected success and actual opportunities creates a specific kind of despair that's hard to articulate without sounding ungrateful.

Your relationship with attention is fundamentally broken. You've been trained to seek validation through likes, follows, and engagement metrics. The dopamine hit of social media approval has rewired how you experience achievement. Real accomplishments that don't translate to content feel somehow less real.

You're so good at advocating for mental health that you sometimes pathologize normal human emotions. Not every bad day is depression. Not every preference is a trauma response. The therapeutic language that helps you understand yourself can also prevent you from experiencing the full range of human messiness.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2017-2027): You're in this decade now. You graduated into economic uncertainty, came of age during a pandemic, and entered adulthood in a world that seems to be actively falling apart. This is supposed to be your 'finding yourself' decade, but it's hard to find yourself when you can barely afford rent. You're building skills, accumulating experiences, trying to figure out what matters. You're also exhausted in ways that feel premature. You shouldn't be this tired at twenty-seven.

Your 30s (2027-2037): This is when things are supposed to stabilize—marriage, kids, career advancement, maybe finally buying a home. Whether that's possible depends on factors largely outside your control: the economy, climate policy, political stability. You'll have more clarity about what you want. Whether you can get it is a different question. You'll watch your parents age, possibly become responsible for their care. The sandwich generation experience—caring for both children and aging parents—might define this decade.

Your 40s (2037-2047): Peak earning years, statistically. You'll probably be managing people, making decisions, wielding whatever authority your career has granted you. Climate change will have reshaped where and how people live. AI will have transformed work in ways we can barely predict. The skills you learned in your twenties will be obsolete, replaced by new skills you'll have to acquire. Adaptability isn't optional. Your kids, if you have them, will be teenagers dealing with problems you can't imagine.

Your 50s (2047-2057): You'll be pre-retirement age but 'retirement' might be a meaningless concept by then. Social Security's future is uncertain. The economy will have gone through several more crises. You'll be the older generation, explaining to younger people what life was like before the climate really started shifting, before AI was everywhere, before whatever comes next. They won't believe you.

Your 60s and beyond (2057+): The world of 2060 is unimaginable from here. Every projection is science fiction. What we know: you'll be among the last people who remember life before the internet was everywhere, before smartphones, before constant connectivity. That perspective will be valuable—or quaint—depending on what kind of world emerges. Whatever happens, you'll have navigated more disruption than any generation in recent memory. That has to count for something.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.9 million people born in 1997. The entire Gen Z generation is about 68 million people in the US, slightly smaller than Millennials but growing as younger members age into adulthood.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more diverse, more digital, and more skeptical. Millennials remember life before the internet took over. You don't. Millennials believed institutions could be reformed. You watched those reform efforts fail. Millennials had hope that got crushed. You started out crushed and built from there.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're practically aliens. Gen X grew up analog, entered adulthood in a booming economy, and got stable jobs and affordable houses before everything went sideways. They have retirement savings. You have student debt. They bought houses in their twenties. You might buy a house in your forties, if you're lucky.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the gap is a chasm. Boomers inherited the post-war economic boom, affordable college, growing wages, and the assumption that each generation would do better than the last. You inherited debt, climate crisis, and a broken political system. Boomers ask why you can't afford a house. The answer is that Boomers pulled up the ladder.

Compared to Gen Alpha (born 2013-2025), you're the older, slightly more grounded version. Alpha is growing up entirely post-smartphone, post-pandemic, post-whatever stability existed before 2020. You at least remember a time before things got this weird. They won't have that anchor.

Your mental health statistics are concerning. Gen Z reports higher rates of anxiety and depression than any previous generation at the same age. Whether this is because you're actually more distressed or because you're more willing to talk about it is debated. Probably both.

But you're also more tolerant, more entrepreneurial, and more comfortable with diversity than any generation before. You've normalized conversations about gender, sexuality, and mental health that were taboo even a decade ago. The world you're building might be more inclusive than the one you inherited—assuming you can keep it from catching fire.

year_events: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone was published
Deep Blue beat Garry Kasparov at chess
